trans-unit.source: Performs asynchronous or synchronous Web page postbacks at a defined interval.
In this topic: - [Introduction](#introduction) - [Declarative Syntax](#declarative_syntax) ## Introduction The Timer control enables you to perform postbacks at a specified interval.
When you use the Timer control as a trigger for an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control is updated by using an asynchronous, partial-page update.
You must include a <xref:System.Web.UI.ScriptManager> object in a Web page to use the Timer control.
You use the Timer control to update an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control by including the timer inside the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control.
Alternatively, you can place the timer outside the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control and set the timer as a trigger.
You can also initiate full postback of a complete Web page by including the Timer control in the Web page and not setting it as a trigger for an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control.
You can run server code when the timer interval has elapsed by creating an event handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event.
In the event handler, you can include code that dynamically adjusts the behavior of the Timer control.
Set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property to specify how often postbacks will occur.
Set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> property to turn the Timer on or off.
> [!NOTE] > The accuracy of when the Timer control posts back to the Web server depends on the accuracy of the ECMAScript (JavaScript) `window.setTimeout` function that is running in the browser.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property is defined in milliseconds.
You must set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property to a value that lets at least one asynchronous postback complete before the next postback is initiated.
When the Timer control is outside an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control, the timer continues to run while the content of the <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control is refreshed.
If a new postback is initiated while an earlier postback is being processed, the first postback will be canceled.
The default value is 60,000 milliseconds (60 seconds).
> [!NOTE] > Adding a Timer control with a small value in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property can generate significant traffic to and from the Web server.
Use the Timer control to refresh the content only as often as necessary.
## Declarative Syntax ``` ```
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> class.

Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control initiates a postback to the server after the number of milliseconds specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval*> property has elapsed.
Use the Enabled property to turn the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control on and off.
When you set Enabled to `true`, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control starts its timer countdown when the Web page is rendered.
On postback, you can change property values in the Enabled property, and the changes will be reflected when the Web page content is rendered in the browser.
If you change the Enabled property and then change it back to its original value during the same postback, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control runs as if no change had been made.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> will initiate a postback; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default value is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Retrieves properties from a <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> object that are passed to the client component that implements timer logic in the browser.

The GetScriptDescriptors method adds the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> properties from an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class to a <xref:System.Web.UI.ScriptDescriptor> object.
The client component accesses the values and sets the corresponding values in script.
An array of type <xref href="System.Web.UI.ScriptDescriptor"></xref>.
Retrieves the client script for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.ScriptReference"></xref> object that contains client script for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control.
Gets or sets the number of milliseconds to wait before initiating a postback.
Use the Interval property to set how often the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control initiates a postback to the server.
You can change the value of the Interval property in server code after a postback, such as in an event handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event.
The accuracy of when the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control posts back to the Web server depends on the accuracy of the ECMAScript (JavaScript) `window.setTimeout` function that runs in the browser.
> [!NOTE] > Setting the Interval property to a small value can generate significant traffic to and from the Web server.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> control to refresh the content only as often as necessary.
When you change the value of the Interval property, the ECMAScript timing code running in the browser will be reset when the updates are rendered.
The number of milliseconds to wait before initiating a postback.
The default value is 60,000 (60 seconds).
The specified value is less than or equal to zero.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick"></xref> event of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event is raised when the number of milliseconds specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property has elapsed either since the Web page was rendered or since the previous <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick> event.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains the event data.
Enables a <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control to raise the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick"></xref> event when a page is posted to the server.
A string with an optional argument to be passed to the event handler.
Renders the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control content to the browser by using the specified <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> object.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> object that is used to render the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control content to the browser.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer.Tick"></xref> event when a page is posted to the server.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> interface.
A string with an optional argument to be passed to the event handler.
Retrieves properties from a <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> object that are passed to the client component.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IScriptControl> interface.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.GetScriptDescriptors%2A> method adds the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> properties from an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class to a <xref:System.Web.UI.ScriptDescriptor> object.
The client component retrieves the values and sets the corresponding values in script.
An array of type <xref href="System.Web.UI.ScriptDescriptor"></xref>.
Retrieves the client script for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IScriptControl> interface.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.ScriptReference"></xref> object that contains client script for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Timer"></xref> control.
Occurs when the number of milliseconds specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval*> property has elapsed and the page is posted to the server.

The Tick event is raised when the number of milliseconds specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Interval%2A> property has elapsed either since the Web page was last rendered or since the previous Tick event.
Handle the Tick event when you have to perform actions during each postback.
To be added.
Overrides the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Visible*> property of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> class to prevent this value from being set.
The `Visible` property is overridden in the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class to prevent setting this property.
The `Visible` property returns `true` if the client component of the <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer> class is included in the Web page, even if <xref:System.Web.UI.Timer.Enabled%2A> is set to `false`.
The `Visible` property returns `false` when it is inside a container, such as an <xref:System.Web.UI.UpdatePanel> control, whose `Visible` property is set to `false`.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the control is rendered on the page; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
A value is assigned to the `Visible` property.
